Luz Marina dreams with her business’ growth and expansion and this is why she’s calling on a Kiva loan, her first financing with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, to buy a small display case and cosmetics that are on sale for the end of year that she’ll use to stock up to be ready for the season of highest sales at Christmas and New Years; she will be able to display them better and have the best sales of the year.

Financial indicators show her business to be profitable and with much growth potential according to its characteristics because she currently has a profit margin of 34%, an indicator from which she starts to continue raising her expected sales having new working capital from her Kiva loan.

loans.use: to buy a small display case and cosmetics.

loans.name: 09.4 Nam Ngan Thanh Hóa Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngọc has a retail business selling cosmetics. She is requesting a loan to purchase household commodities in general to resell.

Ngọc is 47 years old and she is married with 1 child. She lives with 1 dependent in Thanh Hoa city, a urban town in Thanh Hoa province. She is the leader of a 5-member group, the 9.4 Nam Ngạn solidarity group. 

In 2010, Ngọc joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business, and has successfully repaid 1 loan previously. Ngọc has been involved in this business for 5 years, the main hardship that she faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Ngọc hopes for her children to do well in school, for her business to do well, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase household commodities to resell.

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg

texts.en:
Erdenetsetseg is a single mother of four who lives in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Govi-sumber province, Mongolia. Her eldest kid lives independently, the middle one is a college student and the younger two are school students. 

Erdenetsetseg started her meat retailing business in 1996. Over the years she has gained many regular customers and trusted suppliers. Her business is stable and very profitable. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says, "With my income it is hard to support three children. Therefore, I decided to rent another counter in the market". She is requesting 850,000 MNT to purchase more meat.

loans.use: to purchase more meat.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 39 years old a farmer; she is married to Pharis who is a business man. They are blessed with one child aged nine years. She has been rearing poultry for the past two years with the monthly income of KES 9,000 which she uses to support her family.

She is applying for his first loan term from  KADET LTD after being introduced by a KADET staff member. Alice will use the loan to buy chicken feeds and more chicks. 

With the anticipated profit from the business she will educate her child. Her hopes and dreams are to buy a piece of land and venture into mixed crop farming.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and more chicks

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha  is 32 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is a widow and has 5 children 2 of them are currently in school. For the past 6 years, Aisha  has been working hard to manage her business selling charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Aisha  has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal to sell, and will help Aisha  to generate greater profits and to construct a big place for charcoal selling. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to construct rental houses. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Aisha  who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Ayoko Denise

texts.fr: Ayoko Denise âgée de 43 ans n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Ayoko Denise est veuve et mère de quatre enfants. Tous ses enfants sont scolarisés et a sa charge. Ayoko Denise vit seule avec ses enfants. Les diverses charges de la maison son supportées par Ayoko Denise. Pour subvenir à ses différents besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Ayoko Denise vend depuis une dizaine d’année des chaussures friperies dans sa boutique. de façon secondaire, Ayoko Denise vend aussi des habits friperies. Ayoko Denise s’approvisionne à Lomé au TOGO et en france. En vue de renforcer davantage son activité par l’augmentation du stock de ses produits, afin de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Ayoko Denise sollicite pour une deuxième fois l'appui financier de ALIDé. Le crédit consenti antérieurement a été bien remboursé.

loans.use: Acheter des chaussures friperies.

loans.name: Santana Anidia

texts.es:
Santana, de 52 años de edad, estudio hasta tercer grado, tuvo que abandonar sus estudios debido a la falta de recursos económicos que tenían sus padres, estuvo acompañada pero actualmente tiene más de 15 años de estar soltera, porque su esposo la abandono y la dejo cuidando a sus hijos, su primer hijo estudio hasta bachillerato y trabaja en la agricultura en sus días libres y también labora como vigilante en un empresa y está acompañado; su hija se dedica a la elaboración de artículos de artesanías y está estudiando técnico en inglés.  
	
Santana, se dedica a realizar los oficios del hogar y a la elaboración de hamacas y matates, ella aprendió este oficio gracias a sus padres, ella también ha trabajado como empleada doméstica en varios lugares y esto le ha dado la oportunidad de conocer muchas persona, en la agricultura le ayuda su hijo y en la elaboración de jarcia le ayuda su hija.

Santana, necesita el préstamo para comprar abono y herbicidas y para pagar la mano de obra, porque junto a su familia se dedican al cultivo de hortalizas y granos básicos de regadillo.

Santana, sueña con realizarle arreglos a su casa, también desea tener una buena cosecha y que los esfuerzos que está realizando, sean bien recompensados con una buena producción.

loans.use: para comprar abono y herbicidas y para pagar la mano de obra.

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie visits homes offering her product and services. She is a woman of many trades as she provides not only clothing and cosmetics, but also facials and manicures. She is very popular amongst the women in her neighborhood. She started off doing business with a $200 loan from her sister that she used to invest in women’s undergarments. She still sells these items but now offers other types of clothing and cosmetic services. She is requesting the loan in order to continue investing in these items. She also wants to begin selling jewelry and other women’s accessories. Marjorie and her husband, who is also a salesman, have two children.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: Invest in jewelry and other women's accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy clothing at wholesale prices

loans.name: Oktay

texts.en: Q. Oktay is 25 and has lived in Saatli since his childhood. His weak financial situation prompted him to buy a cow some years ago. Now he is broadening his business by buying another cow and a calf. He applied for a loan of 1200USD from Aqroinvest CU.

loans.use: To purchase one cow and one calf

loans.name: Gulsum

texts.en:
Gulsum J. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwest Azerbaijan. She is married and she has one son. Gulsum sells different clothes in the Beylagan city bazaar. She rented a small booth there and she pays a daily tax it. She established her business 16 years ago. She goes to Baku two times a month to buy goods to sell.

Gulsum’s business is not going very well because she hasn't much money to increase the variety of her goods. She needs $700 to buy more kinds of goods and increase her daily income.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: Madina is a mother of 5 children. She lives in Khudat town, in the Khachmaz region. This 56-year-old woman has bred calves for 6 years. Now she needs a loan of $725 to buy a calf to increase the number of her calves.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina is a 45-year-old lady from the village of Gagaifo Lefaga. She has 3 children and this will be her 6th loan from SPBD. She plans to use the loan to help with her plantation, her shop business, and also for renovating her house.  Her grocery shop is open from 7am to 8pm. She’s now focusing more on her goods as her prices are competitive and fair. Tina earns 400 Tala ($160 US) profit from her shop a week and she makes 280 Tala ($112 US) from her plantation by selling 2 sacks of taro at the Fugalei market every Friday.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, knives, cement, and timber for her plantation and small shop

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr:
Born in 1967, Mrs. Ablavi D. is married and has 7 people under her care. Her production of palm seed oil is her principal economic activity. Well known by her customers for the quality and delightful odor of her oil, Mrs D. must now try to meet high demand. To satisfy this demand, she first needs the appropriate funds and resources. She would like to take this opportunity to apply for a loan of $250 in order to purchase the palm seeds necessary for her palm seed oil production. This will allow her to satisfy customer demand as well as attract future loyal customers.

Translated from French by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Née en 1967, Madame D. Ablavi est mariée et a à sa charge sept (7) personnes. La production de l’huile de palme est son activité. Connue par ses consommateurs pour la qualité et l’odeur agréable de son huile, Madame D. Ablavi doit faire face aujourd’hui à de nombreuses demandes. Pour les satisfaire, il faut des moyens. Elle veut à cet effet saisir cette opportunité pour solliciter un financement de $250 afin de s’approvisionner en noix de palme pour la production de son huile. Ceci lui permettra de satisfaire sa clientèle et de fidéliser.

loans.use: Stocking palm seeds for the production of palm seed oil.

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo A. is married with 5 children and she is 40 years old. She comes from Iyano in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been a client with LAPO for the past 2 years. She sells clothes and baby wear. She has been in business since the year 2002. She requests a loan of $875 to buy more clothes and baby wear for sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and baby wear to be sold

loans.name: Barno

texts.en:
Barno K. lives in J.Rasulov, Tajikistan. She is married and has three children.

Barno is engaged in commercial service and trade. She sells socks, women's underwear and men's wear. Having a good assortment, she has many repeat customers. Now she is applying for a business development loan for purchasing a new stock of underwear.

loans.use: Purchasing new underwear stock.

loans.name: Luz

texts.es:
Mrs. Luz C. T. is a member of the Communal Bank. “Saint Rose of Lima,” lives in the San Martin region, in Mariscal Caceres Province, in the district of Juanjui. She is developing her business in three business stands in the Brisas del Huallaga market in the city of Juanjui. Daily, she tends to the residents who visit the market to buy their basic necessities. When her children reached school age, she felt the need to work in order to help her husband with the maintenance of their home. It has been 22 years since she began with small sales of fruits and vegetables. Now, she has established a clientele that knows her, whom she tends to daily for the purchase of their products. With the credit of 1000 PEN ($375 U.S. dollars) that she would be able to pay off within a period of 6 months, she would invest in the purchase of bunches of bananas, oranges, lemons, and other fruits typical to the region, in order to increase business in her three sales stands. Luz shows a lot of energy and vitality, she enjoys the business that she is developing together with her husband and her children and dreams of one day opening a stand for the sales of groceries.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Luz C. T. es socia del Banco Comunal. “Santa Rosa de Lima”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui, desarrolla su negocio en tres puestos de venta en el mercado Brisas del Huallaga de la ciudad de Juanjui, donde diariamente acuden los moradores a comprar productos de primera necesidad Cuando sus hijos iniciaron su etapa escolar sintió la necesidad de trabajar para ayudar a su esposo en la manutención del hogar, es así que hace 22 años se inicia en la venta de frutas y verduras al por menor, actualmente tiene una clientela ya conocida que acude diariamente a comprar sus productos. Con el crédito de S/ 1000.00 el cual pagara en un plazo de 6 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de : plátanos por racimos, naranjas, sapotes, coconas, limones en cientos, shica shica fruto silvestre de la región entre otros, para implementar sus tres puestos de venta. Luz, muestra mucha energía y vitalidad y le gusta el negocio que desarrolla junto a su esposo y sus hijos y sueña con tener un puesto de venta de abarrotes.

loans.use: With the loan, she will buy more products for her sales.

loans.name: Zareena's Group

texts.en: Zareena B., the group leader, resides in Lahore, a big city in Pakistan. She is married and has three kids, all of whom are enrolled in a local school. She is a health worker and her husband make thread reels. He has been making these reels for more than 15 years. Now, they wish to expand their business though a loan.  Zareena B.’s sub group members are: Sumaira B. (who has a family business of manufacturing shoe buckles), Uzma S. (who has an electric store), Rafia B. (who buys and sells vests), and Parween B. (who wants to buy her son a rickshaw.)

loans.use: to expand her thread reels business

loans.name: Aflatun

texts.en: Aflatun A. is a 49-year-old man who keeps calves and cows for dairy and meat sale. He is married and lives with his wife and three children in the small village of Imishli. He started his business in 1984 and at the same time he is a driver. His main financial resource is keeping livestock and to cover family needs, he has decided to purchase more animals. For this purpose he has applied for a loan in the amount of US$ 1200. With this loan he is going to purchase one milch cow for US$ 600 and two calves at US$ 300 each.

loans.use: to purchase one milch cow and two calves

loans.name: Ajik

texts.ru:
Ajik K. lives in the Vahsh region. He is 47 years old, married, and has 4 children. He has secondary education. Ajik has been in the business of growing watermelons for the past 10 years. This year, he collected good amount of crops, but he is having a hard time selling it because of heavy competition. For this reason, he would like to obtain a loan so he could purchase GSM and rent a truck. This will enable him to distribute the watermelons in other regions.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Каюмов Ажик Нурович житель района Вахш . Возраст 47 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее.Ажик вот уже более 10 лет занимается выращиванием арбузов. Ажик в этом году собрал хороший урожай,но не может его реализовать.Так как очень большая конкуренция.Поэтому клиент хочет получить кредит для покупки ГСМ и взять в аренду грузовую машину.После этого Ажик свой товар развезет по другим районам для реализации.

loans.use: Purchase of GSM and rent of truck

loans.name: Sabougnouma (Porte Bonheur) Group

texts.fr:
The members of Sabougnouma group are married, 32 years old on average, and have an average of 8 children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the village of Sikouna 2, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The women of the Sabougnouma group are specialized in the sale of condiments: onions, pepper, tomato concentrate, dried and smoked fish, Magi cubes, greens, vermicelli, salt, etc.

The Sabougnouma group, made up of relatives, friends, and co-habitants, is on its first loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.

They want to use this loan to buy 1 kg of tomato concentrate, 1 packet of Magi cubes, 1 basket of onions, 5 kg of fish and some piles of greens on market days in Fana, Marka coungo, or Santiguila from the wholesalers who attend these weekly markets. The afore-mentioned locations are the traditional place for this group of village women to do their purchasing.

Their sales are made retail and on a cash basis in the village out of their homes or as ambulant salespeople going through the lanes from door to door. Their clientele is mainly composed of women with a few men.

With this loan, they expect to make a monthly average profit of 5000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and invest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont mariés avec une moyenne d’age de 32 ans 8 enfants et vivant dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs époux, coépouses et enfants dans le village de Sikouna 2 sous préfecture de Fana( Région de Koulikoro République du Mali)

Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma se sont spécialisées dans le commerce de condiments : oignon, poivre, concentré de tomate, poissons : séché, fumé, les aromes magi, les feuilles vertes, les vermicelles, le sel de cuisine etc.).

Le groupe Sabougnouma, constitué de parentes d’amies et de convives est à son premier prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso.

Elles veulent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 1 kg de concentré de tomate 1 paquet de cube magi 1 panier d’oignon 5kg de poissons et quelques tas de feuilles vertes les jours de foire de Fana, Marka coungo ou Santiguila auprès des grossistes fréquentant ces marchés hebdomadaires .Les localités ci-dessus citées constituent les lieux d’approvisionnement traditionnel de ce groupe de femmes entièrement villageois.

Elles effectuent généralement leurs ventes en détail au comptant au village à domicile de façon fixe ou ambulante dans des vanes de porte en porte .La clientèle est surtout composée de femmes et de quelques hommes.

Elles comptent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 5000FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir dans l’activité.

loans.use:
purchase of condiments for re-sale

Achat de condiments alimentaires

loans.name: Mary M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Mary M.. She is married and has three children aged two, six, and nine. She also has two additional dependents that she cares for. In 2000, Mary established her genge (small shack selling groceries). Working seven days a week, and one to four hours a day, she earns about 90 USD every month from this business, in which she is assisted by her husband. Mary requires a loan in order to purchase more sugar, rice, soap, and cooking oil in bulk. In the future, Mary plans to expand and establish another business. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for an outdoor shop or stall is "genge." A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general grocery items such as onions, tomatoes, chiles, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and discover they are missing an ingredient.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more sugar, rice, soap, cooking oil in bulk.

loans.name: Noor

texts.en:
Ten years ago, this 46-year-old man was a military officer, but now he has a bicycle repair shop. He is Noor M., the father of 8 children, and a resident of Ningarhar Province. He lives in a rental house which has just two rooms and a small yard.

Noor M. worked as military officer for about 12 years. At that time, he was single, but when he got married, he left his job and started a business, because he thought he might not be able to provide for all his family expenditures on 2000 Afghanis (US$ 40) monthly salary. Therefore he opened a bicycle repair shop, and still now he is working there.

Noor has four sons; the older one is working as a blacksmith, but the three others are studying in public school. Meanwhile they are helping their father in their spare time.

A few months ago, Noor has decided to buy a car to use as a taxi for his son and some equipment for his shop, because he wants to pave the way for his other three sons to just keep at their studying. For this purpose, he needs to expand his business more and increase his daily income. This was the reason that he requested a 50,000 Afghani individual loan from AFSG , to make his dreams come true.

Finally Noor M. hopes the lenders will provide this opportunity for him, to utilize his capability. Also he thanks them a lot.

loans.use: To buy a taxi  and equipment for his shop

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
Beatriz es socia del Banco Comunal Anabella.

Beatriz es madre soltera, tiene 48 años y 2 hijos, Beatriz tiene una tienda en su casa ubicada en el barrio tradicional de Santa Ana, en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, frutas, chupetes que ella misma prepara, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su mama, Además Beatriz vende comida típica los días sábados y domingos, También Beatriz trabaja como ayudante en una chicharronería, durante su ausencia su mama e hijo atienden en su tienda.

Beatriz necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de leche, arroz y azúcar. Los sueños de Beatriz son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener una buena casa, mejorar su local y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Beatriz is a member of the Anabella community bank.

Beatriz is a single mother, she is 48 years old and she has 2 children. Beatriz runs a convenience store from her home located in the Tradicional region of Santa Ana. There, she sells groceries, vegetables, fruit, and home-made candy. She runs this business with the help of her mother. Beatriz also sells traditional foods on Saturdays and Sundays. Beatriz also works as a helper in a food store, and in her absence, her mother and son manage the store.

Beatriz requires a loan in the amount of 1500 soles. The funds will be invested into the purchase of milk, rice and sugar. The dreams that Beatriz holds is to see her children as professionals, to have a good home, and to improve her store and expand her business.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Beatriz requires a loan amounting to 1500 soles to invest in the purchase of milk, rice, and sugar.

loans.name: Denise

texts.es:
La señora Denise, socia del BC Las Trabajadoras, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Tiene 44 años de edad y vive con su esposo y dos de sus 3 hijos que aún dependen de ella. 

Se dedica a la confección y venta de tarrafas para la pesca, así como también cría y vende gallinas de corral. Sus clientes llegan hasta su casa para adquirir sus tarrafas que son muy requeridas porque la ciudad está junto al río Huallaga facilitándoles la pesca. Las gallinas los lleva a vender en el mercado a las personas que venden comida. 

Con este préstamo de S/.1,000, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará hilo nylon en gran cantidad de diferentes pulgadas para la confección de tarrafas que muchas veces también envía a otros lugares cuando sus clientes lo solicitan, también comprará maíz para el engorde de sus gallinas y estar lista para la venta. 

Denise está contenta con el apoyo recibido de Manuela Ramos y los préstamos le permiten crecer en su negocio y obtener ingresos para ella y para su familia. más adelante desea comprar un terreno para construir su casa, porque vive en casa alquilada.

El desembolso de su préstamo fue el 11/10/08
La tasa de interés  de su préstamo es del 3.5%
El monto de su cuota mensual es de S/.  201.70
texts.en:
Mrs. Denise is a member of Workers Communal Bank and lives in the San Martín region, in the province of Mariscal Cáceres, district of Juanjui. She is 44 years old and lives with her husband and two of her three children who are still dependent on her. She works making and selling fishing nets and also raises and sells chickens. Her customers come to her house to buy nets that they need because the city is located next to the Huallaga River, which facilitates fishing. She takes the chickens to the market to sell them to people who sell food. With this loan of 1,000 soles ($325), which she will repay over 6 months, she will buy a large quantity of nylon thread of different sizes to make fishing nets. Many times she sends the nets to customers who live in other places. She will also buy corn to feed her chickens and fatten them for sale. Denise is happy with the support she has received from Manuela Ramos and the loans have permitted her to grow her business and make additional income for her family. In the future she would like to buy a plot of land to build a house because she house she lives in is rented. This loan was disbursed on 10/11/08. The interest rate for the loan is 3.5%. The monthly payment is 201.70 soles ($66).

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy nylon thread and corn

loans.name: Yon

texts.en: Mrs. Yon N. is a 52-year-old widow. She makes a living running a small grocery store in front of her house in Pursat Province. She has four children, three of whom are married and employed, and one single daughter. Her daughter, Ms. Yon Phary, is 20 years old and raises pigs. N. is requesting a loan of 600,000 Riel ($150) to purchase more groceries to sell so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Pablo Emilio

texts.es:
El microempresario Pablo Emilio Malespín Narváez tiene 64 años de edad, es casado con 3 hijos todos mayores de edad y viven en sus propios hogares. El señor Malespín se dedica a la actividad de fotógrafo desde hace 35 años aproximadamente y con esta actividad a podido darle el estudio a sus hijos así como una profesión.

Por el tiempo que tiene de dedicarse a la actividad de fotógrafo el señor Malespín tiene una buena cantidad de clientes quienes lo buscan para actividades de cumpleaños, matrimonios, bautizos, promociones entre otras actividades que los blufileños tradicionalmente celebran y que buscan como guardar esos recuerdos.

Sin embargo por la inconsistencia de los precios del material se requiere comprar en cantidades para de esa manera poder mantener el precio estable por cada fotografía.  Por tal razón requiere del financiamiento para la compra de los siguientes productos:

60 rollos de película 135x36 a US$ 4 dólares cada rollo, 20 cajas de película polaroid a US$ 25 dólares cada caja de película, 5 unidades de tinta para impresora a US$ 30 dólares cada unidad y 5 docenas de baterías AA a US$ 22 dólares cada docena.
texts.en:
Micro-entrepreneur Pablo Emilio Malespín Narváez is 64 years old. He is married and has three children that are already independent. Mr. Malespín has been a photographer for over 35 years, activity that allowed his to pay for his children’s education. After all this time devoted to this profession, Mr. Malespín has acquired a vast clientele that requests for his services for birthday parties, weddings, baptisms, promotions and other reunions traditionally celebrated by the blufileños (inhabitants of Bluefields, Nicaragua) so they can save their memories. However, due to the inconsistency in the price of the material he needs to purchase large amounts of products to maintain a stable price for his services. This is the reason why he is looking for financing to purchase the following items: 60 135x36 film rolls at a price of $ 4 each, 20 Polaroid film boxes at $ 25 each, 5 units of printer ink at $ 30 each and 5 dozens of AA batteries at $ 22 each dozen.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase 60 135x36 film rolls at a price of $ 4 each, 20 Polaroid film boxes at $ 25 each, 5 units of printer ink at $ 30 each and 5 dozens of AA batteries at $ 22 each dozen.

loans.name: Estela

texts.es: La señora Estela, D. 45 años D. edad, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en edad escolar en su casa propia. Se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes y pasamanería desD. hace 2 años, negocio que ha implementado en su vivienda; y con el que respalda el sustento económico D. ella y D. su familia. Estela venD. durante todo el día, le gusta su trabajo porque socializa, y como a ella le gusta mucho conversar se divierte intercambiando ideas con sus clientes D. donD. surgen nuevas amistades. El negocio está yendo muy bien hasta ahora, y eso la motiva para continuar invirtiendo en él. Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP, y con el dinero que solicita quiere mandar a ampliar su negocio, mejorando las estructuras del espacio donD. lo tiene, y también incrementar sus productos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Estela M. D. R. is 45-year-old and lives with her husband and two school-aged children in her own house. For the last two years, she has sold groceries and general goods from a business she initiated from her home. The business provides economic support for Estela and her family. She sells during the day and enjoys her work because of the social aspect that allows her to have fun interacting and exchanging ideas with her customers and even form new friendships. The business has been going very well up to now, and it has motivated her to continue investing in it. This it is her third loan with MFP. With the funds requested Estela will expand her business, improving the physical space and she will also increase the selection of products she offers.

Translated from Spanish by Lisette Artiga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the selection of products and improve the physical space of the business.

loans.name: Nguyen's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Tuyết Phương sinh năm 1973 ( mã số: 010117090028 ). Chị có cửa hang nhỏ bán đồ đông lạnh ( thịt, cá, tôm hải sản,…). Chồng chị cũng phụ giúp chị đi lấy hang về bán phục vụ bà con trong thôn xóm. Gia đình chị vẫn làm nông nghiệp, chăn nuôi lợn. Hai con chị còn nhỏ, đang độ tuổi đi học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 300.000 vnđ/ tuần. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 5.450.000 vnđ để đầu tư mở rộng cửa hàng. Cùng vay với chị còn có:
 Nguyễn Thị Độ sinh năm 1963. ( mã số: 010117090034 ) Gia đình chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp. Hàng ngày, chị nấu rượu, nuôi lợn, chồng đóng than bán cho người dân. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 250.000 vnđ/tuần. Chị tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 5.450.000 vnđ để mua thức ăn cho vật nuôi.
 Đỗ T. Hà sinh năm 1970. ( mã số: 010117090032) Gia đình có trang trại chăn  nuôi, cả cá. Hai con còn nhỏ đang độ tuổi đi học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 250.000 vnđ/ tuần.
 Nguyễn Thị Hồng sinh năm 1976. ( mã số: 010117090029 ) Chồng chị là lái xe, hai con đang đi học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 300.000 vnđ/ tuần. Chị vay mức vốn: 5.450.000 vnđ để phát triển chăn nuôi và đầu tư buôn bán nhỏ.
 Nguyễn Thị Nhạn sinh năm 1960 ( mã số: 010117090031 )bán hang quán tại nhà( thực phẩm, hàng khô,…). chồng là cán bộ hưu trí có thu nhập ổn định. Chị vay mức vốn: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng.
 Cao Thị Tớm sinh năm 1956, ( mã số: 010117090030 ) làm nghề bán hang khô, một con đã đi làm giúp đỡ gia đình. Chị vay mức vốn: 5.450.000 vnđ để mua thức ăn chăn nuôi.
 Nguyễn Văn Trường sinh năm 1974( mã số: 010117090033 ) làm nghề kinh doanh cửa hang ăn uống. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng 300.000 vnđ/tuần.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen T. T. P. (born in 1973, ID: 010117090028) is the owner of small shop selling frozen food such as meat and seafood. Her husband assists her in managing the shop by taking the inventories from the suppliers. In addition to running the small shop, Mrs. P. is also a farmer and currently raising pigs at home. She and her husband have two small, school-aged kids. Her family’s weekly income is about 300.000 VND. In the next round of loan, she would like to borrow 5.450.000 VND to expand her shop. Other members in her group include: - Mrs. Nguyen T. D. (born in 1963, ID: 010117090034) is a farmer. She also makes wines and raises pigs. Her husband sells coal. The family’s weekly income is about 250.000 VND. She would like to borrow 5.450.000 VND to buy food the pigs. - Mrs. D. T. H., (born in 1970, ID: 010117090032) raises poultry and fishes. She has two kids, both of whom are in the school age. The family’s weekly income is 250.000 VND. - Mrs. Nguyen T. H. (born in 1976, ID: 010117090029) would like to borrow 5.450.000 VND to raise poultry and invest in her small shop. Her husband is a driver, and her two kids are still in school. Her family’s weekly income is about 300.000 VND. - Mrs. Cao T. T. (born in 1956, ID: 010117090030) sells dry food in her town. One of her children is now working to assist the family. She would like to borrow 5.450.000 VND to buy more dry food for her shop. - Mr. Nguyen V. Tuong (born in 1974, ID: 010117090033) runs a small restaurant. His family’s weekly income is about 300.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buôn bán nhỏ

loans.name: Fubu

texts.en:
P. is a father of eight children and raises pigs. He lives in Ntasen, outside of GHAPE headquarters. He will use this loan to purchase building materials for a new room he wishes to add on to his two-bedroom house.  
 
This is P.’s tenth loan from GHAPE since he became a beneficiary in 2000. His past loans have been investments for his pig-raising business. The profits from those loans have helped him to send his children to school. This particular loan is for him to be able to complete the building of his house. He plans on contributing by providing labor and will use the loan to buy materials. 

While he has had many trials in his life, from the loss of a child to the death of his mother, P. continues to provide for his children and their needs. P. has been with GHAPE for almost a decade and continues to use them as a resource because he feels comfortable with “their ways.”
 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase building materials

loans.name: Mrs. Sovann Phang Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eleven people living in Preaek Pang village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Sovann P. is 46 years old and is the president of the village bank group. She is also a vegetable seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Et Vuthy, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate vegetables. He needs to purchase more seeds to sow on his field. So, Mrs. Sovann P. decided to ask for a loan to buy ginger seed. She hopes to increase their income and improve her family living conditions with this loan. She has eight children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory, two of whom are laborers, and the remaining three are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy ginger seed to grow on their field.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
La señora Beatriz vive con su esposo el señor Evaristo que es pensionado, pero aparte tienen otro ingreso extra del negocio propio que tienen llamado “Abarrotes Betty “que cuenta con 7 años establecidos. El proyecto que ahora tienen es invertir en la compra de mas mercancía para su negocio; motivo por el cual están solicitando este crédito.
Ellos son una familia carismática, responsable y muy trabajadora.
texts.en:
Beatriz lives with her husband, Evaristo, who is a pensioner. Apart from that, they have other extra income from their own business named "Abarrotes Betty" (Betty's Groceries) which has been in business for seven years. The project that they currently are pursuing is to invest in the purchase of more merchandise for their business, which is why they are requesting this loan. They are a charismatic, responsible and hard-working family.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in their business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy maize, rice, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Tun

texts.en:
Tun S., 66 years old, lives with her family in the province of Kompong Cham in Cambodia. She and her husband are crop growers and the older couple have given birth to eight children: three are single and five are married and have already started a new family. To provide a little more of the family's food needs, two of their single children are working as garment workers.

Tun S. can generate much income from her investment because she is widely known and has farmed since she was young. Tun S. is applying for a loan to purchase a small-sized plantation near her house in order to grow cane trees during the rainy season. (She and her husband are pictured).

loans.use: To purchase a small-sized plantation

loans.name: Mily

texts.es:
La señora Mily, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Shatojinas Laboriosas”, vive en el Ex Aeropuerto cdra. 01, Distrito de Shatoja, Provincia El Dorado, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 45 años 04 hijos, uno que aun dependen de ella.

Mily, una mujer que se siente capaz de cumplir sus metas, por lo que ella y su esposo, decidieron implementar su propio negocio  de venta de maderas. 
Se inicio en el negocio desde muy joven, actividad que le ayudo a realizarse como mujer y así saco adelante a sus hijos y hoy ya son profesionales, al mismo tiempo esta muy agradecida con Manuela Ramos, por brindarle el apoyo para mejorar su negocio.
Hoy en día, continua con el mismo negocio, tiene muy buena acogida y cuenta con clientes fijos ya fidelizados, también trabaja con diferentes empresas.

Con el préstamo de S/ 1000.00, desea invertirlo comprando maderas como: cedro, alfaro, paliperro, rifari, anacaspi. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá comprando combustible para hacer su aserrín y luego venderlas. 

Mily, esta muy contenta  y se siente una mujer muy realizada, con más ganas de seguir adelante y hacer realidad sus sueños. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por ayudarla en iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarial.
texts.en:
Mily belongs to the "Shatojinas Laboriosas" Community Bank and lives in the district of Shatoja, El Dorado province, department of San Martín. She is a married 45-year-old mother of four children, one of whom is still dependent on her. Mily is a women who feels like she can achieve her goals, which is why she and her husband decided to start up their own business selling timber. She started the business when she was very young, and it helped her grow as a woman and make headway for her children, who are now professionals. At the same time she is very grateful to Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for providing the support she needed to improve her business. Today, she continues her work and the business is very well received with many permanent and loyal customers. She also works with different companies. Mily is requesting a loan of 1000 soles, which she plans to invest in the purchase of timber such as ceder and other types of wood. Part of the money will also be used to purchase fuel to make and then sell sawdust. Mily is very satisfied and feels very fulfilled but she still has a strong desire to keep moving up in life and make her dreams a reality. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business and also helping the many other women who want to grow their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase different types of wood

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen tiene 47 años, vive con sus 3 hijos de 20, 18 y 16 años en la casa de su abuela. Desde hace más de 15 años se dedica a la venta de chicharrones (plato a base de carne de cerdo frita) en un puesto que tiene en una calle bien transitada de su ciudad desde la tarde hasta que llega la noche. De esa manera ella y sus hijos venden esta comida típica de su zona y debido a su buena sazón y calidad en su preparación ha adquirido muchos clientes estables que siempre consumen su platillo, por lo que es rentable su negocio. Carmen está planeando implementar en un local  para que se convierta en un restaurante. Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, ella es una de las personas que siempre  recuerda a sus compañeros de banco comunal sobre la importancia de trabajar en unidad y en equipo. Ahora que está nuevamente solicitando este crédito se compromete a seguir trabajando  con los mismos ideales de éxito. El dinero que está solicitando será para que adquiera nuevos cubiertos para la atención de sus clientes, así como para la compra de una cocina nueva.
texts.en:
Carmen is 47. She lives with her three children; ages 20, 18, and 16, in her grandmother’s house. For over 15 years she has been selling “chicharrones” (a dish made from fried pork) in a stand that she has on a well traveled street in her city. She and her children sell this food that is typical to her zone from the afternoon until night time. Because of her good seasoning and the quality of preparation, she has acquired many stable customers who always eat her dishes. Her business is profitable. Carmen is planning to set up a place that she can convert into a restaurant. This is her third loan with MFP. She is one of the people who always reminds her colleagues in her community bank about the importance of being united and working together as a team. Now that she is asking for this loan, she promises to keep working with the same ideals of success. The money she is asking for is to get new cutlery for her customers and to buy a new stove.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a stove and utensils for her business

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla B. makes a living primarily from raising pigs for sale. She is 50 years old, married and has 3 adult children. She is from the village of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Perla has been in this business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Perla joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Perla is requesting a loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Benkadi 4 De (Benkadi  A Tingolé) Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe BENKADI 4 de l’association BENKADI A sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 48   ans, 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à TINGOLE  chef lieu d’une commune rurale de la sous préfecture de FANA, 2ème région administrative de la république du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’avoir un soutien  financier pour la réalisation de leurs activités hivernales. Leurs activités sont axées sur la culture du sorgho et de l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième expérience avec l’institution et tous les prêts passés ont été correctement remboursés.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour  acheter, de l’engrais, de l’herbicide, des petits matériels et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 25 hectares.
Après les récoltes, une partie de leur production est auto consommée et l’autre partie est vendue dans les marchés hebdomadaires de  Marka-Coungo et Fana, surtout au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30 000FCFA après la campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of BENKADI 4 group of BENKADI A association are married women who average 48 years of age and 4 children. They live mostly in polygamous families at TINGOLE, main rural town of FANA sub-prefecture, 2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali.They work with microfinance insititution, Soro Yiriwaso in order to have financial support to execute their rainy season businesses. Their businesses are centered on the cultivation of Sorghum and peanuts.They are on their fifth loan with the institution and all past loans had been correctly repaid. This new loan will be used to buy fertilizers, herbicides, small equipment and to pay the cost of weeding and plowing so as to maintain 25 hectares. After harvesting, a portion of their produce is eaten by themselves and the rest is sold in the weekly markets of Marka-Coungo and Fana, mostly for cash to customers made up of men and women.They intend to make an average profit of 30 000FCFA after the farming season.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Plowing, fertilizers, herbicites, weeding and small materials

loans.name: Irene

texts.es:
Irene es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza.
Irene es casada, tiene 42 años y 4 hijos, Irene se dedica a la siembra de papa, producto que vende en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, además Irene se dedica a la crianza de animales.
Irene necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de abono para la siembra de papa.
Los sueños de Irene son construir su casa, educar a sus hijos y comprar un carro.
texts.en:
Irene belongs to the Bonanza Village Bank. She is 42-years-old, and married with four children. She earns her living growing potatoes, which she sells at the wholesale market in the city of Ayacucho. She also raises animals. Irene is seeking a loan of 1200 soles, which she'll use to buy fertilizers for growing potatoes. She dreams of building her house, educating her children, and buying a car.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for growing potatoes.

loans.name: Mrs. Eng Phann Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
A village bank loan group which consists of fifteen people is located in Pouthi Reamea village in Kandal province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Eng P. is the village bank president. She is the wife of a fisherman, Mr. Chi Chorb. He does not have enough fishnets and this affects his income. Mrs. Eng P. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishnets for her husband’s fishing. She is a 39-year-old mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study. 

Twelve members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK H. a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK H. a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets for her husband’s fishing.

loans.name: Lidia

texts.en:
Lidia is a member of the Gangilonga borrower group in Knyanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 1 year old.

Lidia has owned a business for 2 years , she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 70,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Lidia  first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 100,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities for local beer.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Lidia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy mor comodities for local beer

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia O. the one in front wearing red t-shirt is from the village of Panalsalan Plaridel Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Cecelia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Cecelia owns & operates a fishing business selling seafood products such as fish, shells "kinason" and etc. to local community members. Cecelia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cecelia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Cecelia is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP' which will be used to purchase additional seafood products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Cecelia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seafood to sell

loans.name: Jesusisa

texts.en:
Jesusisa Sta. A. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old. Jesusisa is married and has 1 adult-aged child. To make a living, Jesusisa owns & operates a business in the food sector, butchering and selling meat. Her main source of income for the business comes primarily from butchering & selling dressed chicken in the local community. She also engages in pig raising. Jesusisa has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jesusisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jesusisa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional supplies & working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Jesusisa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional supplies of meat & working capital

loans.name: Alberto

texts.en:
Albert is a 45-year-old business man. He lives in Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabela together with h is wife and children. Aside from being a farmer, Albert also has a sideline which involves retailing. Albert is married to Gemma, and has two school-aged children. He works hard for the needs of his family. He must be responsible to meet their daily needs and he want his children to finish their studies. He doesn’t want them to be like him who did not finish his studies. He hopes to provide them good future through complete education.

Albert is engaged in retailing big animals such as cows and carabao (water buffaloes). He purchases animals directly from Pangasinan and sells them in various villages of Isabela. Each animal costs a lot and he needs more capital to increase the stock that he buys. He is requesting a loan for his buy-and-sell business. He hopes that KIVA lenders can help him expand his business so that he can support the studies of his two children.

loans.use: Buy and sell cows and carabaos (water buffaloes)

loans.name: Phal

texts.en: Mrs. Phal H. lives in Daeum Rumdael village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Touch Ra, are farmers who own a plot of land to grow rice. They face a problem because the field is infertile. Mrs. Phal H. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides to support the rice field, in order to make it more productive. She has three children who are all enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Do-Better-Tin Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni. They have come to SMT for the very first time to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 500,000, they will be able to add more stocks to their businesses, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school, feeding them well, and clothing them.

Sonita K. on the left is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni, twenty-four years ago. She is single with two children. Sonita has been selling rice, palm-oil (the post popular cooking oil), and groundnuts/peanuts for three years now. Sonita will use this loan to expand her business by buying more bags of rice and groundnuts, and more gallons of palm-oil.

loans.use: Expand her business by adding more rice, palm-oil and ground-nuts

loans.name: Serifat

texts.en:
Serifat is 33 years old. She is married and has two children, the eldest of whom is just 3 years old. Her husband is a contractor and he helps to support their family. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client.

Serifat sells groceries and medicine at retail prices. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries and medicine to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and medicine to sell

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.es:
Bernardo tiene 47 años, vive con su esposa Rosalina de 45 años. Tiene 6 hijos, pero sólo vive con 4 de ellos: Mariela de 22, James de 19, Kevin 15 y Kitty de 11 años; por quienes se desvive para brindarles un futuro mejor. Su casa es propia y la pudo conseguir luego de haber pasado muchos sacrificios que parecían interminables.

Él se dedica a la agricultura, desde muy joven aprendió todo lo necesario para estas labores, lo cual le permite sembrar papa, olluco, alverja y habas. Con esta actividad logra cubrir actualmente  las necesidades de su familia. Sus 3 hijos mayores lo ayudan en la actividad agrícola y lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que tiene unida a su familia.
Paralelamente, se dedica paralelamente a la venta de leña, aunque este trabajo es algo sacrificado sigue adelante porque quiere asegurar el futuro de sus hijos, además los ingresos que percibe son bastante rentables por lo que planea invertir en la siembra de más terrenos para obtener una mayor productividad.

Su puntualidad de pago en su banco comunal, ha logrado que trabaje con mucho entusiasmo y ser un ejemplo a seguir para sus compañeros; tal es así que este es su noveno crédito consecutivo con MFP. Bernardo tiene planeado invertir el dinero que solicita en la compra de varios sacos de semilla de alverja, habas y flores de melón, para empezar con su proyecto de producir en mayor cantidad.
texts.en:
Bernardo is 47 years old and lives with his wife Rosalina, who is 45. They have six children, but only four live with them: Mariela (age 22), James (age 19), Kevin (age 15), and Kitty (age 11). Bernando struggles in order to provide them with a better future. He purchased his own home after spending many years making sacrifices that appeared to be endless.

Bernardo is engaged in agriculture. As a young man, he learned everything about farming so that he could grow potatoes, ulluco, peas, and beans. Farming enables him to cover what he currently needs for his family. His three older children help with the agricultural duties. What he enjoys about his work is having his family together.

In addition, Bernardo sells firewood. Although this business is somewhat of a sacrifice, he continues with it because he wants to secure his children’s future. His earnings are quite profitable, so he plans to invest in more land for higher productivity.

Bernardo has been punctual with his payments to his Communal Bank. He managed to work with great enthusiasm and become a role model for his peers. This is his ninth loan with MFP. He plans to use the money to purchase several bags of seeds to grow peas, beans, and melon flowers so that that he can produce these crops in larger quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds

loans.name: Cecelia's Group

texts.en:
Cecelia C. is from the city of Danlugan, Pagadian City. She is 59 years old. Cecelia is the group leader of a two-member loan group with PMPC. While each member of the group receives individual loans, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

To make a living, Cecelia owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Cecelia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. She joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Cecelia from PMPC; she has successfully repaid previous loans.

Cecelia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, for growing vegetables

loans.name: Siliman

texts.en:
Siliman D. sells clothes in the market and is requesting a loan to buy more clothes to sell.  Siliman is 45 years-old and a widow.  She has two children and both go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a supermarket.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.  BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry P. is from the village of Salimbal, Lugait Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old, married, and has three grown children. Cherry makes and sells food for a living, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. 

In 2009, Cherry joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cherry successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI.

Cherry is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Cherry from HSPFI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a food and snack business.

loans.name: Imelda's Group

texts.en:
Imelda S. is from the village of Buena Suerte, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 47 years old. Imelda is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Imelda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda and her husband own & operate a business providing electronics repairs in the local community. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand her service

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl C. is from the village of Brgy. Sta. Cruz, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is twenty-eight years old. Sheryl is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Sheryl owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Sheryl has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Sheryl joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheryl is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Sheryl's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-nine branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Serfina Aoko

texts.en:
Serfina M. is 50 years old and from Manyatta in Kisumu. She is a widow with eight children, two of whom are boys and six are girls. Her first born is 30 years old and her last born is six years old. 

Serfina has a tree nursery that she has been running for the last five years. She is applying for her first loan from KADET after being introduced by another client who has previously benefited from their loans. She plans to use the money to buy different species of trees to add to her stock in the nursery.

She hopes to use the profits made to pay school fees for those of her children who are still in school and also to cater for the family's upkeep. Her desire is to purchase a piece of land and build a permanent house for her family so that they can have better shelter.

loans.use: To buy various species of trees for her nursery

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en: Lorena O., 36, uses her income to send her four children to school.  She is a rice farmer and has been growing rice since 1998.  She likes growing rice and dreamed that someday she will have a big farm.  Lorena would like a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and to pay for labor.

loans.use: Farm supplies, payment for labor.

loans.name: Water Side Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 500,000, they will be able to add more stock to their business inventories, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school and feeding and clothing them. 

Marie S. (pictured left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni 45 years ago. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a businessman and some of her children are attending school – two are married and three are in secondary school. 

Marie sells rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil).  She has been doing this business for many years now. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying rice and palm oil wholesale.

loans.use: Buy rice and palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary O. makes a living selling green vegetables in the local market and has applied for a loan to buy fish to sell. She is 33 years old and married to a teacher. She has three children, all of whom are enrolled in school. With the extra income made possible by this loan, she hopes to expand her shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell to her customers

loans.name: Tem

texts.en: Tem S., 53, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. grows rice and raises pigs for an income of US $1.80 per day. Her husband is a farmer and palm juice seller, earning an income of about US $1 per day to help cover the family expenses. S. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase cows to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy cows to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Tiessiri (Courage) Group

texts.fr:
Tièssiri est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien et elles  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans et au moins 3 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les jus de fruits et légumes, les habits et chaussures etc. 
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 ans. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Fanta S. est un membre du groupe Tièssiri qui vend des boissons fraîches (jus de fruits, boissons locales à base de jujube, de dah, de tamarin, de citron etc.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, à la veille du mois de carême, une importante quantité d’ingrédients : dah rouge, tamarin, jujube, citron  beaucoup d’arômes etc. 
Elle se procure  dans le grand marché de Koutiala. Elle vend  ses boissons à la maison, dans les  quartiers, au comptant à une clientèle diverse et variée. Tandis que Les membres du groupe Tièssiri comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 90 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Fanta S. compte réaliser 120 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Tièssiri is a group of women of Koutiala who know each other well and they live in traditional big families with their husbands, children and other parents. They are on average 33 years old with at least 3 children. This group of women trade in various articles such as fruit juices and vegetables, clothing and shoes etc. To increase the scope of their activities, the members decided to join the credit program Soro Yiriwaso 2 years ago. They are on their third group loan and all the preceding loans were properly repaid. Fanta S. is a member of the Tièssiri group which sells cold drinks (fruit juice, local drinks containing jujube, roselle, tamarind, lemon etc) She intends to use her loan to buy, the day before the month of Lent, a large quantity of ingredients: roselle , tamarind, jujube, lemon, many flavours etc she gets in the large market of Koutiala. She sells her drinks from the house, and in the neighborhoods, for cash to various and varied customers. While the members of the Tièssiri group intend to borrow an average of 90.000FCFA each during this cycle, Fanta S. intends to borrow 120.000FCFA. In addition to the refunding of the loans, they use part of the income to meet the current expenses of the family. They wish to see this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso grow so that stocks are not scarce.

Translated from French by Mark Latour, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase ingredients for juices

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena F. sells fresh tomatoes as well as canned tomatoes, garden eggs (eggplant), plantain and pepper at Abura. Abena has been through senior high school. She lives with her husband, who is a driver, and five children.

Abena has been in this trade for ten years. She responsibly supports her husband in taking care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to use the new income from her business to save to buy a shop at the market to sell her goods in.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita P. is from the village of Makawa Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old. Teresita is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in her business. This will be the eleventh loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in her business

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida R. is from the town of Banga. She is 62 years old. Zenaida is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Zenaida has been farming for more than 35 years now. 

Zenaida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Zenaida from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Rafiq

texts.en:
Rafiq R. is a hardworking man who works in the cattle raising business. He is married with four children. He works hard to provide everything his family needs. Presently, Rafiq is sacrificing and working hard to make his business grow. He buys young calves, then raise them and sells for a profitable price to the local butchers.

He is requesting a loan of 1000 AZN that will allow him to purchase young calves. He plans to feed and raise these cows. His goal is to then get the most return from the sale of the cows' milk products. This will be his first loan with AqroInvest CU and Kiva. His experience and our evaluation shows he is qualified to receive the loan.

loans.use: To purchase three young calves

loans.name: Makongo K.k. Group

texts.en:
Francisca M. is in her early thirties and is married with one child. She owns a second hand clothes shop and has been running it for one year. The shop is open daily between 8 am and 8 pm and earns Fransisca a good monthly profit. 

This will be Fransisca's first motisha loan with Tujijenge Tanzania.  A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. Fransisca aims to use this loan to buy used clothes at wholesale prices so that she can increase her stock. 

Fransisca will share this loan with her loan group Makongo K.K., which totals 8 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Francisca is in the back row, in the middle.

loans.use: Increase stock of used clothes.

loans.name: Rebozo De Mujer Group

texts.es:
Este grupo  se llama “Rebozo D. Mujer “, porque dentro D. la comunidad se elaboran rebozos y son mujeres las que los hacen, este grupo está ubicado en Tenancingo estado D. México este grupo está conformado por 10 integrantes.
La señora Julia S. es casada, tiene  una hija y  seis varones, en la actualidad ella vive con cuatro hijos en su domicilio, uno D. sus hijos es profesor y el otro está radicando en Estados Unidos  D. Norte América.

La señora Julia es originaria D. Tenancingo, quiere su crédito para invertir en una miscelánea que tiene aproximadamente catorce años, lo que ella pretenD. es darle crecimiento a su negocio, comprando más productos dado que la comunidad está alejada D. la cabecera municipal y la gente requiere variedad D. mercancías, D. esta forma ayuda a la gente ofertando los productos y su familia pueD. tener un sustento diario.
texts.en:
This group is called “Rebozo D. Mujer” (Woman’s Shawl) because shawls are manufactured in this community and it’s the women who make them.  The group is located in Tenancingo in the state of México and it has 10 members.

Julia S. is married.  She has a daughter and six sons.  She is currently living with four of her children in her home.  One of her sons is a teacher and the other lives in the United States.

Julia is from Tenancingo.  She wants a loan to invest in the general store she’s had for about fourteen years.
